issues.description:
Function BuyTorpedo(int256,uint256,address,bytes32,bytes32,uint8) retrieves the transaction origin (tx.origin) using the ORIGIN opcode. Use msg.sender instead.
See also: https://solidity.readthedocs.io/en/develop/security-considerations.html#tx-origin
issues.title: Use of tx.origin

issues.description:
A possible integer overflow exists in the function `BuyTorpedo(int256,uint256,address,bytes32,bytes32,uint8)`.
The addition or multiplication may result in a value higher than the maximum representable integer.
issues.title: Integer Overflow

issues.description: A reachable exception (opcode 0xfe) has been detected. This can be caused by type errors, division by zero, out-of-bounds array access, or assert violations. This is acceptable in most situations. Note however that `assert()` should only be used to check invariants. Use `require()` for regular input checking.
issues.title: Exception state

issues.description:
Function ValidTorpedoScore(int256,uint256,bytes32,bytes32,uint8) retrieves the transaction origin (tx.origin) using the ORIGIN opcode. Use msg.sender instead.
See also: https://solidity.readthedocs.io/en/develop/security-considerations.html#tx-origin
issues.title: Use of tx.origin

issues.description: This contract executes a message call to to another contract. Make sure that the called contract is trusted and does not execute user-supplied code.
issues.title: Message call to external contract

issues.description:
Multiple sends exist in one transaction, try to isolate each external call into its own transaction. As external calls can fail accidentally or deliberately.
Consecutive calls: 
Call at address: 4800
issues.title: Multiple Calls

issues.description: A possible transaction order independence vulnerability exists in function BuyName(bytes32). The value or direction of the call statement is determined from a tainted storage location
issues.title: Transaction order dependence

issues.description: The contract account state is changed after an external call. Consider that the called contract could re-enter the function before this state change takes place. This can lead to business logic vulnerabilities.
issues.title: State change after external call
